title: Reassurance Needs
description: Discover how you need to be reassured and comforted.

questions.text: What type of reassurance do I need most from you?
choices: Seeing you make me a priority

therapeutic.rationale: Reassurance types align with love languages and attachment needs. Hearing 'I love you' fills words-of-affirmation needs; physical touch provides bodily reassurance; being prioritized addresses abandonment anxiety; commitment actions build trust through proof. The type that reassures you most reflects your deepest attachment need.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different reassurance types mean your natural reassurance may not land. The verbal-reassurer may not realize their partner needs touch; the action-taker may not verbalize. Give reassurance in your partner's preferred form.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reassurance types mean your comfort will naturally register. You understand what reassures because it reassures you too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What type of reassurance makes you feel most loved and secure? Does your partner provide this? What would help them understand your need?

questions.text: How often do I need reassurance in our relationship?

therapeutic.rationale: Reassurance frequency reflects attachment style intensity. Frequent-needers have anxious attachment activation; daily-needers have moderate needs; stress-triggered seekers are context-dependent; rare-needers have secure attachment or avoidant suppression. There's no right amount—the goal is understanding and meeting each other's needs.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different reassurance frequencies can strain relationships. The frequent-needer may exhaust the rare-needer; the rare-needer may seem cold to the frequent-needer. Negotiate a rhythm that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared reassurance frequency makes comfort natural. You'll give and need similar amounts of explicit reassurance.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How often do you need reassurance from your partner? Is this need being met? What happens when it's not?

questions.text: What's my biggest fear in our relationship?
choices: That we'll grow apart over time
That I'm not enough for you

therapeutic.rationale: Relationship fears reveal core attachment wounds. Stop-loving fear indicates abandonment anxiety; growing-apart fear indicates drift anxiety; not-enough fear indicates inadequacy; independence-loss fear indicates engulfment anxiety. Understanding your partner's core fear helps you avoid triggering it and provide specific reassurance.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different core fears drive different protective behaviors. The abandonment-fearer may cling; the independence-loser may distance. Neither is wrong—both are protecting against their deepest wound.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared core fears suggest similar attachment wounds. You'll understand each other's anxiety because you share it. Be careful not to trigger your shared vulnerability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your deepest fear about your relationship? Where does it come from? Does your partner know and respond to this fear?

questions.text: How do I prefer you to reassure me when I'm worried about us?
choices: Talk through my concerns with me
Hold me and provide physical comfort
Give me space to self-regulate first

therapeutic.rationale: Worry-reassurance preferences reveal how our attachment system calms. Talking processes anxiety externally; physical comfort provides co-regulation; commitment reminders address abandonment directly; space allows self-regulation. Providing the wrong reassurance when your partner is worried can escalate rather than calm.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different worry-reassurance needs cause mismatch. The talk-through person may feel dismissed by the space-giver; the space-needer may feel smothered by pursuit. Ask: 'What would help right now?'
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared worry-reassurance means you'll naturally comfort each other effectively. You provide what helps because it's what would help you.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you're worried about your relationship, what actually helps you calm down? Does your partner know what to do?

questions.text: What makes me feel most certain about your love?
choices: How you respond when I'm struggling

therapeutic.rationale: Love-certainty signals vary by attachment needs. Regular verbalization provides explicit confirmation; prioritization provides choice confirmation; consistency provides reliability certainty; crisis-response provides 'earned' certainty. Knowing what makes your partner feel certain about your love helps you provide that specific evidence.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different certainty signals mean you may feel differently loved despite equal love. The verbal-certainty person may doubt despite prioritization; the consistency-seeker may not register verbal expressions as deeply.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared certainty signals mean you'll both feel loved by the same things. You understand what proves love because it proves love to you too.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel most certain your partner loves you? What evidence do you look for? What would increase your certainty?
